column3: U-85 (Oblt. Eberhard Greger). Sunk on 14 April 1942 in the North Atlantic off Cape Hatteras
column6: by gunfire from the US destroyer USS Roper.

column3: U-352 (Kptlt. Hellmut Rathke). Sunk on 9 May 1942 in the North Atlantic south of Cape Hatteras
column6: by depth charges from the US Coast Guard cutter USCGC Icarus.

column3: U-157 (KrvKpt. Wolf Henne). Sunk at 2150hrs on 13 June 1942 in the Gulf of Mexico north of Havana
column7: by depth charges from the US Coast Guard cutter UCGC Thetis.

column3: U-158 (Kptlt. Erwin Rostin). Sunk on 30 June 1942 in the North Atlantic west of the Bermuda
column6: by depth charges from a US Mariner aircraft (VP-74 USN/P-1).

column3: U-215 (KrvKpt. Fritz Hoeckner). Sunk on 3 July 1942 in the North Atlantic east of Boston
column6: by depth charges from the British anti-submarine trawler HMS Le Tiger.

column3: U-701 (Kptlt. Horst Degen). Sunk on 7 July 1942 in the North Atlantic off Cape Hatteras
column6: by depth charges from a US A-29 Hudson aircraft (396th Bomb Sqn USAAF).

column3: U-576 (Kptlt. Hans-Dieter Heinicke). Sunk on 15 July 1942 in the North Atlantic off Cape Hatteras
column6: by depth charges from two US Kingfisher aircraft (VS-9 USN) and gunfire from the US motor merchant Unicoi.

column3: U-166 (Oblt. Hans-Günther Kuhlmann). Sunk on 30 July 1942 in the Gulf of Mexico south-east of New Orleans
column6: by depth charges from the US patrol craft USS PC-566.

column3: U-754 (Kptlt. Hans Oestermann). Sunk on 31 July 1942 in North Atlantic south of Nova Scotia
column6: by depth charges of a Canadian Hudson aircraft (113 Sqn RCAF/625).

column3: U-176 (KrvKpt. Reiner Dierksen). Sunk on 15 May 1943 in the Florida Straits north-east of Havana
column6: by depth charges from the Cuban patrol craft CS 13.

column3: U-521 (Kptlt. Klaus Heinrich Bargsten). Sunk on 2 June 1943 in the North Atlantic north-east of Norfolk
column6: by depth charges from the US patrol craft USS PC-565.

column3: U-84 (Kptlt. Horst Uphoff). Sunk on 7 August 1943 in the North Atlantic south-west of Bermuda
column6: by a Fido homing torpedo from a US Liberator aircraft (VB-105 USN/B-4).

column3: U-856 (Oblt. Friedrich Wittenberg). Sunk on 7 April 1944 in the North Atlantic south-east of Boston
column6: by depth charges from the US destroyer USS Champlin and the US destroyer escort USS Huse.

column3: U-550 (Kptlt. Klaus Hänert). Sunk on 16 April 1944 in the North Atlantic east of New York
column6: by depth charges and gunfire from the US destroyer escorts USS Gandy

column3: U-869 (Kptlt. Hellmut Neuerburg). The boat was sunk on Feb 11 1945 off New Jersey
column5: 73.02W by Hedgehogs and depth charges from the American destroyer escorts USS Howard D. Crow and USS Koiner.

column3: U-866 (Oblt. Peter Rogowsky). Sunk on 18 March 1945 in the North Atlantic south-east of Halifax
column6: by depth charges from the US destroyer escorts USS Lowe

column3: U-548 (Oblt. Erich Krempl). Sunk on 19 April 1945 in the North Atlantic south-east of Halifax
column6: by depth charges from the US destroyer escorts USS Reuben James and USS Buckley.

column3: U-857 (Kptlt. Rudolf Premauer). Missing since 30 April 1945 in the North Atlantic off the US East Coast.
U-879 (Kptlt. Erwin Manchen). Sunk on 30 April 1945 in the North Atlantic east of Cape Hatteras
column7: by depth charges from the US patrol frigate USS Natchez and the US destroyer escorts USS Coffmann

column3: U-853 (Oblt. Helmut Frömsdorf). Sunk on 6 May 1945 in the North Atlantic south-east of New London
column6: by depth charges from the US destroyer escort USS Atherton and the US patrol frigate USS Moberly.
